sp.l: Ay, ay, hang him, hang him!

sp.speaker: Whiting.
sp.p: Here, Neighbour Bull-finch, here's the very Halter he sold me, to cure all Diseases.
sp.stage: [They throw the Halter over his Head.

sp.speaker: Trick-well.
sp.l: Hold, Gentlemen, hold, have but
A moments patience—
I have but one short Prayer to make, of an Hour or two long,
And then you may do as your compassion shall direct you.

sp.speaker: Noisy.
sp.l: How, Gentlemen,
Does this Rogue look as if he e're said his Prayers?—
Come, come, hang him up, up with him, I say.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ay, ay, hang him, hang him!
sp.stage: [As they are going to hang him up, he slips the Halter, and runs away.

sp.speaker: Trick-well.
sp.l: Help, help, Murder, Murder!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Stop him, stop him, stop him.

div.head: SCENE the Last.
div.stage: Enter: Maggot, Clitander, Amaranta, and Isbell: Trick-well meeting them, as running, and out of Breath.

sp.speaker: Maggot.
sp.l: How now Trickwell! How dost do, man?
Prithee tell me, how dost like the Roman Sport
Of fighting with Wild Beasts?

sp.speaker: Trick-well.
sp.l: Gad, I'le get a Warrant, and bind 'em all over—
I'le Crown-Office the Dogs;
And if they don't find it worse, than being buffeted by Satan,
I'le be their Bond Slave.

sp.speaker: Isbell.
sp.l: Oh, my Dear, I am glad to see thee
In the Land of the Living—
I was horribly afraid, my Love,
That my Ladyship had been spoil'd, and
That I must have put on the Garments of Widdow-hood,
Before thou had'st made me a Jointure.

sp.speaker: Trick-well.
sp.l: Ay, ay, That was my greatest grief, too, Isbell;
For 'twould have vexed any Saint alive,
To have been hurried out of his Matrimony,
And Five Thousand Pounds to boot—
But come, they have had their ends, and all's well—
So that now, if you please, Gentlemen,
We'll have a Song and a Dance or two,
And then every Man to his own Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Clitander.
sp.l: With all my Heart!

sp.speaker: Maggot.
sp.l: Come then, sit down, and let the Musick strike up.

div.head: A NEW MASQUE, CALL'D Love and Riches Reconcil'd.
div.stage: Then Enters Plutus on one side of the Stage, attended by Empire, Labour and Industry; and Cupid on the other, attended by the Graces; they range themselves on each side of the Stage, and after a while, Plutus and Cupid advance towards one another.

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: POOR silly Diminutive Chit—
What fancy bewitches,
Thy little fantastical Wit,
Now to compare with the great God of Riches?

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: Blind Idol of the World, produc'd from dirt,
Thou, that neither Temple hast, nor Court:
Whilst I both Gods, and Men controul,
Enshrin'd in every Humane Soul.

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: Sure Heav'n and Earth did a Governour lack,
When they made a young Fowler,
Their Lord Controller,
That never was worth a rag to his Back.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: Pride and Envy; makes thee bear me a grudge;
But Plutus, know, I scorn to be my own Judge.

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: How wilt thou avoid it?

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: Let Momus decide it.

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: Momus!

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: Momus!

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Come, come away,
Make no delay;
Why, why d'you stay?
Come, come away.
sp.stage: Enter Momus, attended by Hymen, Hebe, Peace, and Reason.

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! What do I see,
The aged God of Wealth,
With this young little Elf?
Well, and how d'ye both agree?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: 'Tis thee we call—

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: 'Tis thee we call.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: By whom the Gods—

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: By whom the Gods,

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Are quitted——

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Or condemn'd.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: When they're at odds.

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: Be just, and end the strife,
Who bears the greatest sway in humane life;
This little Dandy-prat,
Or I, that am so glorious, plump, and fat?

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: I am prepar'd to hear both sides,
And then to judge as Reason guides.
sp.stage: [Here follows a Dance; then the Graces Address themselves to Momus.]

sp.speaker: Euphrosine.
sp.l: Daughters of Jove, and Themis, we
Keep the bright Gates of Heav'n, and see
What passes in the Seats above,
Where all the Gods give way to Love.

sp.speaker: Thalia.
sp.l: His uncontroul'd Commands,
Forc'd Neptune's Trident from his Hands;
Phoebus his Quiver durst not own,
And Hercules his Club laid down:
Mavors he made his Helmet quit,
Tore Hermes's Wings from off his Feet;
And which was yet a greater wonder,
Great Jove disarm'd of all his Thunder.

sp.speaker: Aglaia.
sp.l: No wonder then,
That Mortal Men,
So feebly shou'd resist his Charms,
To whom the Gods surrender up their Arms.
No wonder then,
That mortal Men,
So feebly shou'd resist his Charms,
To whom the Gods surrender up their Arms.

div.stage: [Here follows a Dance of a little Boy dress'd like a Cupid.]
After the Dance, Hebe and Hymen sing the following seven Lines in two Parts.

sp.speaker: Hebe and Hymen.
sp.l: Short is what we have to say:
In the Circle of Mankind,
At Cupid's heels you'l surely find
Us, always merry, blithe and gay;
None, none can tell,
His steps so well,
For we trace him ev'ry day:

sp.speaker: Heb.
sp.l: From sporting,

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: To Courting;

sp.speaker: Hebe.
sp.l: From Courting

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: To Billing;

sp.speaker: Hebe.
sp.l: From Billing

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: To Willing;

sp.speaker: Hebe.
sp.l: From Willing,

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: To Wedding;

sp.speaker: Hebe.
sp.l: From Wedding

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: To Bedding.
Thus round, round, around, in a circle whirl'd,
'Tis our little God Cupid, sustains the World.
sp.stage: [Here follows a Dance of two Girls.]

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: Come, I have something to propose,
Will bring ye quickly to a close.
Cupid and Plutus together.
Then to the point, and set us right.

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: Two Matches are confirm'd this Night;
Love makes the One, the other Gold,
Now which is longest like to hold.

sp.speaker: Cupid.
sp.l: The Dowry'd Wife imperious grows,
And fills the House with noise:

sp.speaker: Plutus.
sp.l: As loud the Monyless too crows,
For want of my brave yellow Boys.

sp.speaker: Momus.
sp.l: Then Plutus, take the Day thy self,
The Night I give this little Elf:
Thus reconcil'd, shake hands—'Tis more
Then ever Momus did before—
So with a Jolly Dance, dismiss,
The Brides and Bridegrooms to their Bliss.
sp.stage: A general Chorus, with a Dance.
sp.l: So with with a jolly Dance dismiss,
The Brides and Bridegrooms to their Bliss.
sp.stage: After the Masque, Maggot rises and speaks.

sp.speaker: Maggot.
sp.p: Well, Clitander, since I find you take your bad Bargain so contentedly, I'le give thee a brace of Thousands to make thee amends—My Daughter shall never be upbraided for a Portionless Wife, I'le tell thee that, Boy.
sp.l: Clitander, Kind Sir, I humbly thank you;

l.hi: Young Men in heat of Blood, their Flames approve,
But when all's done, 'tis Money binds our Love.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: And for my part, I often have been told,
There's nothing like dancing to the Musick of Gold.
